moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Nf6 3. Nf3 e6 4. Nbd2 Bd: Dream position for a London player.
moves.7... Nfd7 8. Qg4: ...this starts serious hostilities, and forces black to lose castling rights.
moves.8... Rg8 9. Bd3 g6: It's not the proper time to play the dark squares.
moves.10. h4 c5 11. c3: Providing c2 to my B, and controlling the center.
moves.11... Nc6 12. Nf3 Qb6 13. O-O-O: Risky, of course, but my attack is coming.
moves.13... a5 14. h5 a4 15. hxg6 hxg6 16. Ng5: ? Maybe not the right one. This allows...
moves.17. Qh4: Faint counterattack, but with no definite break in plan.
moves.17... Nxd3+ 18. Rxd3 a3 19. b3: ?? I thought about this move before, but now, with the R on e3, it is a fatal mistake that could have costed me the game.
moves.20... Rf8: ...but now I have to face the R issue.
moves.23. Rxb3 Nf6 24. Qg7 Nh5 25. Rxh5: I thought I needed this in order to keep chances...
moves.25... gxh5 26. Nh7 b5 27. Nf6+: Not NxR, QxN, and everything is over.
moves.28... Kd8 29. Bg5+ Kc7: ?? The move I was waiting for.
moves.30. Be7: From here, white is winning material, but with black's answer, it becomes mate. See:
moves.32. Bxc5 Kxc5 33. Qc7#: Material is even, but... the "residual advantage" after the exchanges was... decisive!
